history.content: Having anyone else (including private tutors) debug or help write your code is considered academic dishonesty under 61B’s policy. I encourage you to email us if you are feeling overwhelmed and we can set up a meeting to discuss resources and your path forward in the course, but paying someone to do your work (yes, debugging is part of the “work” of 61B) is not the way to go. Source: am CS 61B head TA

children.subject: The problem is that if you are hiring someone to help with a specific assignment, it is almost impossible not to end up basically having them just dictate code to you. In particular, this student seems interested not in the kind of conceptual tutoring that private tutoring offers, but rather in having someone guide them though the project.

To build on what Alex is saying, hiring a private tutor to help with a project very much puts a student in danger of crossing the line on academic dishonesty because it will be very difficult for someone who is neither on course staff nor currently working on the project to provide insight without having their hands on the code - even TAs often cannot debug without downloading the code and that is after both doing the project and understanding the staff solution. Additionally, the spirit of our collaboration policy is so that students (who theoretically are peers in terms of the material and not significantly advanced) bolster their own understanding by explaining their ideas to others. 

As a full time software engineer, I am sure that you come across problems that you don’t immediately know the answers to in your work. And I’m sure you recognize the difference between discussing with peers who also are working towards finding the answer and getting the solution explained to you by someone who has already come across the problem and solved it.

If any student is reading this and is feeling overwhelmed with the class, that is completely reasonable. I highly encourage you to email cs61b@berkeley.edu so we may set up a 1:1 appointment with you and figure out how you can tackle the class. We have many resources and we are always working towards making them bigger and better.

And again I want to emphasize, gitlet is hard to debug. But it is 100x harder to debug if you are looking at someone else’s code because we give students full creative control in their implementation. While I cannot physically stop you from hiring a tutor, the chance that someone will be able to help you without violating our policy is exceedingly low. I suggest you proceed with caution if you choose to do so.

Hi,
Former student here and a fan of CS61B. I think the head TA’s advice is not a good one, and factually misleading. In CS61B website, under “project collaboration policy”, it’s stated:

Permitted with Extreme Caution:

  • Looking at someone else's project code to assist with debugging. Typing or dictating code into someone else's computer is a violation of the "By You Alone" rule.
  • Help with debugging and explaining conceptual gaps, given one does not write or type actual code or for the student, is actually one of the best ways to learn the material and improve (source: was a student once and now a full time software engineer). If students feel like the course staff does not allow enough time to answer questions, by all means the staff should allocate more time. I’m aware of budget issues (was part of a committee concerning that as a student), but that shouldn’t be a reason to turn back on students when they’re asking for help.
  • Also, regardless of the extra resources course staff should allocate, I would advise the students to check other resources on campus, like UPE or HKN office hours (though in some cases they might not provide a sufficient replacement to course staff, one of which is debugging actual projects).
<md>If you choose to have a private tutor help you, view this list: @15591</md>
Eh should’ve pressed “reply” but I’m from my phone so excuse my horrible piazza etiquette.

I really appreciate your answers, but they extremely lack any empathy. Have you never struggled in a course in your life?

They are asking for help from course staff. They want course staff to help them. They are desperate to get your attention. When they failed to do so, they want to get outside help, which is honestly admirable - they are willing to pay for help they should get for free. They are clearly stating that they want to ask conceptual questions and get help with debugging their project, rather than Google “gitlet CS61b GitHub” and see thousands of answers. You should help them, not reprimand them.

In industry, no two people are working on the same piece of code, so I’m not sure I understand the corollary. When asking for help debugging, they will definitely look at your code and try to provide some help with their experience, without knowing the solution to your problem. Exactly like a private tutor will do, and the opposite of what another student will do (though, I strongly recommend students to help each other. It has many other benefits as you mentioned).

And last thing. Students who want to cheat will 100% do that, with extremely low chance of getting caught (even the legendary MOSS can’t stop them). Most students at cal are extremely honest, smart, and hard working. Help them, don’t reprimand them for asking for help because “someone might accidentally reveal them the answer”. This completely defeats the purpose of high education. Stop thinking like everyone at Cal is trying to cheat, help them understand the material.

If Prof.Hug / Prof.Hilfinger will not agree with my statements, I’m willing to come to school in person and discuss this.

history.content:
Hello,

I am looking for a CS 61B tutor that could serve as an extra resource for projects, specifically gitlet. I haven't found much success with office hours, especially when there's a 10 minute max. I've been led astray quite often in office hours, in fact, because I might have a slightly different implementation than what the TA would have, and the TA's would only give a quick look at my code and give me faulty advice. I really need someone who can spend time with me to debug my code and help clarify any conceptual issues I may have while coding. I'd appreciate meeting twice a week, perhaps for 30 minutes to an hour, where needed to get guidance on what I am misunderstanding and how to approach the project. I've really struggled with this class, and haven't done well on past projects, so I fear I may have significant gaps in knowledge that I simply can't gain elsewhere in the class. If anyone is open to this, I'd appreciate you dropping your contact info, and I'll email you to discuss logistics. Thank you in advance!
history.subject: CS 61B Tutoring
